excerpt: King's summer residence with period 18th century furnishings & iconic terraced vineyards.
detail_description: Sanssouci Palace, a summer residence of the king with 18th-century furnishings and iconic terraced vineyards, embodies the ideas of the Age of Enlightenment. Potsdam, where it is located, was designed to be a picturesque pastoral dream that reflects residents' connection with nature and reason. The city is known for its interconnected lakes and cultural landmarks like Sanssouci Palace, part of Germany's largest World Heritage Site.
name: Sanssouci Palace

detail_description: Dutch Quarter is located at the eastern end of the Brandenburger Strasse, south of the Bassinplatz. Visitors can explore a vibrant farmers market that takes place every weekday and on Saturday mornings. The market offers a variety of regional and organic produce grown by small farmers, creating a colorful and aromatic experience for all who attend.
name: Dutch Quarter

excerpt: Historic palace, now a hotel & Museum with tours, previously the site of the 1945 Potsdam Conference
detail_description: Cecilienhof Palace, located in the northern end of Neuer Garten park in Potsdam, is a historic site with a rich and complex history. Originally built for Crown Prince Wilhelm of Prussia and his wife Duchess Cecilie, the palace was their residence until February 1945. The couple's support of Hitler led to their forced departure from Cecilienhof during World War II.
name: Cecilienhof Palace

excerpt: Formal gardens around Sanssouci Palace, with notable buildings like Sanssouci Picture Gallery.
detail_description: Sanssouci Park, located east of the city center in Potsdam, is a renowned attraction known for its formal gardens and historical buildings. Built as a summer palace by Prussian King Frederick the Great, it rivals Versailles with its intimate Rococo style and numerous temples and follies in the surrounding park.
name: Sanssouci Park

excerpt: Art museum with international exhibitions & a collection of impressionist paintings.
detail_description: The Museum Barberini, located in the heart of Potsdam, is a renowned art museum that houses an exceptional collection of impressionist paintings donated by Hasso Plattner, the founder of SAP. The museum showcases an extensive array of Impressionist and Post-Impressionist masterpieces from artists like Monet, Renoir, Caillebotte, and Signac. In addition to its permanent collection, the museum hosts temporary exhibitions in collaboration with international partners.
name: Museum Barberini

excerpt: Vast, ornate, 18th-century palace with lavish, rococo interiors, hung with numerous paintings.
detail_description: The New Palace, also known as Neue Palace, is an opulent 18th-century palace located in Sanssouci Park. Commissioned by Frederick the Great and completed between 1763 and 1769, it boasts lavish rococo interiors adorned with numerous paintings. Initially intended for state events and official guests after the 7 Years War, it later became the official residence of Kaiser William II.
name: New Palace

excerpt: High-tech cinematic rides & stunt shows, plus film sets & kids' adventures in a movie-based park.
detail_description: Filmpark Babelsberg, situated in Potsdam, Brandenburg, is a captivating theme park that celebrates the enchanting world of cinema and television. It offers an immersive experience into the art of filmmaking with high-tech cinematic rides, stunt shows, film sets to explore, and engaging adventures for kids. As one of the oldest and largest film studios globally, it provides a unique glimpse into Germany's rich film history from its golden age to contemporary contributions.
name: Filmpark Babelsberg

excerpt: Founded by Crown Prince William in 1833, this forested Havel River park is a UNESCO-listed site.
detail_description: Park Babelsberg, established in 1833 by Crown Prince William, is a UNESCO-listed site located along the Havel River. The park covers 114 hectares and features notable attractions such as the Flatow Tower, Glienicke Bridge connecting Potsdam with Berlin's Wannsee district, and Peacock Island with its 18th-century royal castle.
name: Park Babelsberg

excerpt: This museum in an ornate 1685 structure offers a modern gallery with exhibits on film history.
detail_description: Nestled in a grand 1685 building, Filmmuseum Potsdam is a haven for film enthusiasts. The museum's main attraction is the permanent exhibition 'Dream Factory - 100 Years of Film in Babelsberg,' which delves into the illustrious history of the Babelsberg film studios, the oldest in the world.
name: Filmmuseum Potsdam

excerpt: 19th-century heritage village with 13 buildings, one of which houses Russian colonial life museum.
detail_description: Museum Alexandrowka is a 19th-century heritage village in Potsdam, built between 1826 and 1827 by King Friedrich Wilhelm III. This UNESCO-protected site features 13 wooden houses that offer a glimpse into Russian colonial life. The museum within one of the buildings showcases the history of the colony. Visitors can explore the village and enjoy traditional Russian cuisine at a restaurant housed in one of the buildings.
name: Museum Alexandrowka

excerpt: Potsdam is a city on the border of Berlin, Germany. Sanssouci Palace was once the summer home of Frederick the Great, former King of Prussia. On the grounds of the complex, the Renaissance Orangery Palace overlooks Italian-style gardens with fountains. Historic Mill offers city views. English gardens surround neoclassical Charlottenhof Palace. The 19th-century Roman Baths were built in several architectural styles.
detail_description: Potsdam, a city bordering Berlin, Germany, is home to the magnificent Sanssouci Palace, once the summer residence of Frederick the Great. The palace complex includes the Renaissance Orangery Palace and its stunning Italian-style gardens with fountains. Visitors can also enjoy panoramic views from the Historic Mill and explore the neoclassical Charlottenhof Palace surrounded by English gardens. Additionally, Potsdam boasts the 19th-century Roman Baths featuring diverse architectural styles.
name: Potsdam

excerpt: Neo-classical 18th-century country house in leafy gardens, open for guided tours May to October.
detail_description: Charlottenhof Palace, located in Sanssouci Park in Potsdam, is a neoclassical 18th-century country house that served as the summer residence for Crown Prince Friederick Wilhelm. Built by Prussian King Frederick the Great, it is often compared to Versailles and features Roman-inspired architecture both inside and out. The palace is open for guided tours from May to October and offers visitors a glimpse into its rich history and royal connections.
name: Charlottenhof Palace

detail_description: When considering your itinerary in Potsdam, don't miss out on the opportunity to explore the Neues Palais, also known as the New Palace. This grand royal residence, which began construction in 1763, showcases stunning Baroque architecture. The palace is surrounded by a vast park that offers pleasant walking paths and even a bike track for visitors to enjoy. Keep in mind that parking can be quite expensive, so it's best to arrive early if you're driving.
name: Potsdam, Neues Palais

excerpt: A Renaissance-style palace from 1851-64, with lookout tower & orangery wings still used for plants.
detail_description: Orangery Palace, a luxurious Renaissance-style palace built between 1851 and 1864 in Potsdam's Sanssouci Park, is a must-visit destination. The palace features a lookout tower and orangery wings that are still used to store exotic plants during winter. Visitors can also explore other nearby palaces like Charlottenuhof and Sanssouci, as well as the charming Dutch Quarter with its red brick buildings dating back to the early 1700s.
name: Orangerieschloss

excerpt: Landmark Expressionist building with bust of Einstein, offering guided tours by appointment.
detail_description: The Einstein Tower, also known as Einsteinturm, is a significant landmark located in the Albert Einstein Science Park in Potsdam, Germany. Built in 1924, this expressionist building houses a large solar telescope designed to conduct experiments supporting Albert Einstein's theory of relativity. Visitors can arrange guided tours to explore the observatory and its functioning solar laboratory. Although reaching the tower requires a short hike, it offers an enriching experience for science enthusiasts and families alike.
name: Einstein Tower

excerpt: Indoor trails through tropical rainforest flowers & trees, with exotic reptile & fish, plus dining.
detail_description: Biosphäre Potsdam is a captivating indoor tropical rainforest that offers an immersive experience for families and visitors of all ages. Nestled in the heart of Potsdam, this unique destination features lush greenery, exotic plants, colorful birds, and a variety of tropical animals. With over 20,000 tropical plants and 350 different species, it provides an enchanting environment for exploration.
name: Biosphäre Potsdam

excerpt: Sprawling 18th-century lakeside garden with lush meadows, Gothic structures & the Marble Palace.
detail_description: New Garden, also known as Neuer Garten, is an expansive 18th-century lakeside garden in Potsdam. This picturesque landscape seamlessly blends nature and architectural marvels, including the royal parks of Babelsberg and Sanssouci. The area also encompasses UNESCO World Heritage sites such as Glienicke Park, Pfaueninsel (Peacock Island), and Sacrow Park with the Heilandskirche (Church of the Redeemer) standing by the water.
name: New Garden

excerpt: Schinkel-designed neoclassical church with a columned cupola, offering tours & a viewing platform.
detail_description: Nestled in the heart of Potsdam's Old Market Square, St. Nicholas Church (Nikolaikirche) is a stunning example of neoclassical architecture designed by Schinkel. Constructed between 1830 and 1837, this magnificent church boasts a striking dome that soars to 77 meters, making it one of the tallest structures in the area.
name: St. Nikolaikirche Potsdam

excerpt: The restored Chinese teahouse built 1755–1764 offers gilded statues, 18th-century porcelain & tours.
detail_description: The Chinese House in Sanssouci Park is a restored teahouse built between 1755 and 1764, featuring gilded statues and 18th-century porcelain. Situated above the Sanssouci Palace, it offers breathtaking views of the formal gardens, reflecting pool, and terraced planting beds that reflect the Prussian kings' vision of harmony between nature and man.
name: Chinese House in Sanssouci Park

excerpt: Built in 1755, this large Gothic Revival gate is a busy meeting place near many bars & restaurants.
detail_description: Nauener Tor, also known as Nauen Gate, is a significant historical landmark in Potsdam. Constructed in 1755, it stands as one of the earliest examples of English Neo-Gothic architecture on the European continent. Commissioned by Frederick the Great, this imposing gate was designed to enhance the city's view along its main shopping streets.
name: Nauener Tor

excerpt: Accessible by ferry only, this 67-hectare island & nature reserve is home to many peacocks & trails.
detail_description: Nestled in the serene waters of the Havel River, Pfaueninsel, or Peacock Island, is a captivating 67-hectare nature reserve that can only be reached by ferry. This enchanting island is not just a haven for peacocks but also boasts picturesque trails perfect for leisurely strolls. As part of a UNESCO World Heritage Site that includes Potsdam's stunning landmarks, Pfaueninsel features historical significance dating back to the Iron Age and showcases remnants from its royal past.
name: Pfaueninsel

excerpt: Classically styled 19th-century belvedere, with landscaped gardens & stunning views from the towers.
detail_description: Belvedere Castle on the Pfingstberg is a 19th-century architectural gem surrounded by beautifully landscaped gardens. Modeled after the Villa Medici in Rome, this romantic pleasure palace offers stunning panoramic views of Potsdam and its surroundings from its two 25-meter-tall towers.
name: Belvedere Castle on the Pfingstberg

excerpt: Late 18th-century royal summer residence, clad in red Silesian marble & set in a lakeside park.
detail_description: Marmorpalais, also known as the Marble Palace, is a stunning late 18th-century royal summer residence located in a lakeside park. The palace is made of red Silesian marble and features neoclassical brick architecture. It served as a royal residence for the Hohenzollern family until the early 20th century and has been recognized as a UNESCO site since 1990.
name: Marmorpalais

excerpt: Built in the 18th century by Frederick II, this ornate gallery houses European masterpieces.
detail_description: The Sanssouci Picture Gallery, constructed in the 18th century by Frederick II, is a part of the Sanssouci Palace complex and serves as a home to European masterpieces. It was designed to house Frederick the Great's art collection and remains the oldest surviving royal museum in Germany. While its exterior may seem modest compared to other Prussian palaces, the interior boasts elaborate designs.
name: Sanssouci Picture Gallery

excerpt: Neo-Gothic palace built in 1833 sitting in extensively landscaped English-style gardens.
detail_description: Babelsberg Palace, a stunning Neo-Gothic structure built in 1833, is nestled within the picturesque Park Babelsberg in Potsdam. The palace is surrounded by beautifully landscaped English-style gardens and sits along the idyllic river Havel. Notably, it played a role in Cold War history as the location of the first agent exchange between the Soviet Union and the USA in 1962, depicted in the film 'Bridge of Spies.'
name: Babelsberg Palace

detail_description: Glienicker Brücke, a small bridge connecting Wannsee in western Berlin with Potsdam, holds historical significance as the site of Cold War spy exchanges between the USA and the Soviet Union. The bridge offers picturesque views of Jagdschloss, Glienicke Palace, and the river Havel. Once closed to civilians during spy exchanges, today it is a peaceful spot with little trace of its dramatic past.
name: Glienicker Brücke

detail_description: Located in Potsdam, the Hans Otto Theater is a major cultural hub offering a diverse program of plays, musicals, operas, and ballet performances. The theater's new building on the Schiffbauerdamm has been hosting shows since 2006, while the rococo theatre in the Neues Palais continues to showcase its historic charm from the 18th century. Visitors can also explore contemporary architecture at the Nikolaisaal Potsdam concert hall.
name: Hans Otto Theater

excerpt: Prussia's King Frederick William IV had a hand in the design of this church in the palace gardens.
detail_description: The Church of Peace, also known as Friedenskirche, is a picturesque church located in the Marlygarten near the green grid. It was designed with the close involvement of Prussian King Frederick William IV and built by court architect Ludwig Persius. The church reflects the deep religiosity of the king and features impressive architecture. Modeled after an Early Christian basilica in Rome, it houses a valuable apse mosaic dating back to 1108.
name: Friedenskirche

excerpt: Rococo palace with banquet halls, guest apartments & paintings of Venus & Ovid's Metamorphoses.
detail_description: New Chambers, also known as the New Chambers of Sanssouci, is a Rococo palace originally built as an orangery to accommodate guests of Frederick the Great. This guest palace in Potsdam features banquet halls, guest apartments, and paintings depicting Venus and Ovid's Metamorphoses. The lavish rooms are adorned with ornate gold features and decorated by leading artists of the time. The central Jasper room boasts jasper-lined walls and a ceiling painting of the goddess Venus.
name: New Chambers

detail_description: The Jan Bouman Haus, located in the Dutch Quarter of Potsdam, is a museum that offers insight into the Dutch history and architecture of the area. Named after Jan Bouman, a renowned royal Prussian director of construction, this museum showcases the history and design of the quarter from its establishment in the 18th century to its role during World War. Visitors can explore iconic houses and learn about their historic significance.
name: Jan Bouman Haus

detail_description: The Lindenstraße Memorial Center is a museum in Potsdam that tells the story of state terror during the Nazi dictatorship. The museum features exhibits about the history of the house where Adolf Hitler was once imprisoned, as well as displays about how people were persecuted under Nazi rule. It is an interesting and shocking museum that is definitely worth visiting if you're in Potsdam.
name: Stiftung Gedenkstätte Lindenstraße

excerpt: Opulent neoclassical rotunda with a frescoed dome offering panoramic views of Sanssouci Park.
detail_description: Belvedere on the Klausberg is a stunning neoclassical rotunda located in Sanssouci Park, Potsdam. Commissioned by Frederick the Great, it was part of his plan to beautify the park. The palace offers panoramic views of the surrounding area and is a favorite spot for nature lovers due to its serene and picturesque setting. Despite some muddy paths during certain seasons, visitors are captivated by the natural charm and tranquility of the place.
name: Belvedere on the Klausberg

excerpt: German classics like pork knuckle & schnitzel in an airy spot with a shaded terrace & Potsdam views.
detail_description: Kades Restaurant "Am Pfingstberg" is a popular spot in Potsdam, known for serving traditional German dishes like pork knuckle and schnitzel. The restaurant offers a charming atmosphere with a shaded terrace and stunning views of the city from its location on Mount Pfingstberg. It's a favorite among locals and families who appreciate the authentic local cuisine and the opportunity to enjoy one of the best panoramas of Potsdam.
name: Kades Restaurant "Am Pfingstberg"

detail_description: Alter Markt is a historic square in Potsdam, featuring striking monuments such as the Church of St. Nicholas and the old town hall with its golden atlas sculpture. The square also houses the Potsdam Museum, which recently returned to its original location after more than a century. Additionally, the Brandenburg State Parliament is located on Alter Markt in a reconstructed palace that was inaugurated in 2014. This historic city center offers visitors the opportunity to explore significant landmarks like the City Palace and St.
name: Alter Markt

excerpt: Home to Germany’s main Weimar-era film studio, leafy Babelsberg is now known for Filmpark Babelsberg, a movie-themed amusement park with recreations of famed German sets. The sprawling, rugged Babelsberg Park includes a turreted neo-Gothic castle, a mill, and several architectural follies. Residential Weberviertel is a historic district full of quaint, single-story, 18th-century weavers’ homes with painted shutters.
detail_description: Babelsberg is a charming area in Germany, renowned for its historical significance as the main Weimar-era film studio location. Nowadays, it's famous for Filmpark Babelsberg, an amusement park with replicas of iconic German sets. The expansive and picturesque Babelsberg Park features a neo-Gothic castle, a mill, and various architectural follies. Additionally, the residential Weberviertel district showcases quaint 18th-century weavers' homes with painted shutters.
name: Babelsberg

detail_description: City Palace, originally built in the 18th century, was a significant building in Potsdam until it was destroyed. However, it has been reconstructed and now serves as the seat of the Brandenburg state parliament. The tour also includes visits to other historic sites such as the Dutch Quarter and the Russian colony of Alexandrowka.
name: City Palace
address: City Palace, Potsdam, Am Alten Markt 1, 14467 Potsdam, Germany

detail_description: The Steam Engine House, also known as the Dampfmaschinenhaus or Mosque, is a unique and remarkable industrial structure located in Babelsberg Park in Potsdam. Built between 1843 and 1845, this building was designed by Ludwig Persius and features a distinctive "Norman" style with a mix of simple forms and embellishments.
name: Steam Engine House

detail_description: Studio Babelsberg AG, located in Babelsberg near Potsdam, has a rich history of film production dating back to the 1920s. It has been the filming location for numerous iconic films, from silent classics to modern blockbusters. Visitors can explore behind the scenes at Filmpark Babelsberg and enjoy thrilling stunt shows. The Filmmuseum Potsdam showcases the studio's history and its global impact on filmmaking.
name: Studio Babelsberg AG

detail_description: When in Potsdam, a must-visit is the Alter Markt, also known as the Old Market Square. It serves as the historical heart of Potsdam and is renowned as one of Germany's most picturesque squares.
name: Alter Markt

excerpt: Berlin's sprawling locality features a popular beach, numerous historic sites & restaurants.
detail_description: Wannsee, located in Berlin, is a vast area known for its popular beach, historic sites, and diverse dining options. It's an ideal stop on the way to Potsdam or back to Berlin if you have extra time for a day trip. You can explore the Wannsee area and visit the Babelsberg film studios before or after heading to Potsdam for sightseeing and perhaps enjoying a cup of coffee.
name: Wannsee

excerpt: The Brandenburg Gate, a neoclassical triumphal arch completed in 1791 & an iconic city landmark.
detail_description: The Brandenburg Gate is a neoclassical triumphal arch that stands as an iconic landmark in Potsdam. Built between 1770 and 1771, it replaced a medieval gate and was commissioned by Frederick the Great to commemorate victory in the Seven Years War. The gate is located at the end of Brandenburger Strasse and serves as the grand entrance to Potsdam from the west. It features distinct designs on each side and leads to a beautiful square when passed through.
name: Brandenburg Gate

excerpt: Restored 18th-century windmill with milling displays on 3 levels & views from the 3rd floor gallery.
detail_description: The Historic Mill of Sanssouci, located near the Sanssouci Palace in Potsdam, is a restored 18th-century windmill that offers visitors a glimpse into its milling displays on three levels. Originally built in the mid-18th century and reconstructed after being destroyed during WWII, this Dutch-style mill showcases old milling equipment and features a viewing platform on the third floor that provides stunning views of the surrounding park.
name: Historic Mill of Sanssouci

detail_description: The oldest of the Potsdam city gates, Jagertor, is home to depictions of hunting dogs taking down a deer. The gate is also one of the most beautiful places in Berlin, and if you want to feel like you are in a fairytale, Sansoucci should be your destination - its green gardens are simply lovely. With incredible views all around, it is perfect for a day out.
name: Jägertor Potsdam

excerpt: Picturesque Italianate villa complex in 15th-c. country style, with pavilions, gardens & pergolas.
detail_description: The Roman Baths is a fantastic historical landmark in the city of Bath, England. The baths were built by Emperor Constantine the Great in AD312 and are one of the most famous tourist destinations in the country. The complex consists of several pavilions, gardens and pergolas, making it a wonderful place to spend a morning or afternoon. The baths also have a museum which is well worth visiting for anyone interested in history.
name: Roman Baths

excerpt: 1,000 years of city history, plus art & cultural exhibits, showcased in a historical building.
detail_description: The Potsdam Museum - Forum for Art and History offers a comprehensive display of the city's rich heritage, spanning over a millennium. Housed in a historic structure, visitors can explore captivating exhibits that delve into the art and culture of Potsdam. The museum also boasts an impressive lecture hall, providing an ideal setting for educational talks and presentations.
name: Potsdam Museum – Forum für Kunst und Geschichte

excerpt: University arboretum & botanical garden featuring greenhouses with 10,000 species of plants.
detail_description: The Botanical Garden in Potsdam is a vast expanse of greenery, maintained by the University of Potsdam. With 8.5 hectares of land, it features an extensive arboretum and botanical garden with over 10,000 species of plants housed in its impressive greenhouses.
name: Botanical Garden of the University of Potsdam

excerpt: Ruins featuring a 23m-high 19th-century tower next to a water basin created by Frederick the Great.
detail_description: The Norman Tower on the Ruinenberg is a historic landmark dating back to the Middle Ages. It is a 23-meter-high tower built in the 19th century and features beautiful architecture and decor. Today, it is used as a retreat for the Crown Prince Frederick, who enjoys relaxing by looking out over the tranquil waters of lake Grienericksee from its lofty perch.
name: Normannischer Turm auf dem Ruinenberg

excerpt: This former Soviet detention center now houses preserved prison cells & history exhibits.
detail_description: The Memorial and Meeting Place Leistikow Street Potsdam in Potsdam, Germany preserves the prison cells, carcasses, barriers, frames and remains of the building where Soviet military investigators held prisoners during the Cold War. The museum is quiet and overwhelming, with scary and threatening displays illustrating how Russia's machine became redundant with professional STASI becoming self-sufficient.
name: Memorial and Meeting Place Leistikow Street Potsdam

detail_description: The Pump House "Moschee" in Sanssouci Park is an amazing building from the past that was used to pump water to the impressive fountain in Sanssouci Park. It's now a technology museum, and visitors can learn about the history of pumps and how they've changed over time. The facade is beautiful with two different tones, and it looks like a minaret from far away.
name: Dampfmaschinenhaus „Pumpenhaus / Moschee“

detail_description: The impressive Obelisk standing in the center of Potsdam is a reminder of the power and might of ancient Egypt. Built in 1838, it is one of the few remaining examples of an Egyptian obelisk still standing in situ. The monument was erected to commemorate Prince Friedrich Wilhelm and Princess Marie Louise, who were married here in 1817.
name: Obelisk
